TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS:  Sandy-skeletal, mixed, mesic, shallow Xeric Torriorthents

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Lazan very gravelly coarse sand--forestland.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)  The surface is covered by approximately 60 percent gravel, 5 percent cobbles, and 1 percent stones.
A1--0 to 3 cm; pale brown (10YR 6/3) very gravelly coarse sand, brown (10YR 4/3) moist; weak fine subangular blocky structure; soft, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; few very fine roots; many very fine interstitial pores; 50 percent gravel; neutral (pH 7.0); clear smooth boundary.  (3 to 10 cm thick)
A2--3 to 10 cm; pale brown (10YR 6/3) very gravelly loamy coarse sand, brown (10YR 4/3) moist; weak fine subangular blocky structure; soft, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; few very fine roots; many very fine interstitial pores; 50 percent gravel; neutral (pH 6.8); clear wavy boundary.  (7 to 20 cm thick)
Cr--10 cm; highly fractured granitic rock.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Mineral County, Nevada; in the Wassuk Range northwest of Willow Canyon; approximately 1,000 feet south and 2,400 feet east of the northwest corner of section 32, T. 7 N., R. 30 E.; USGS Lucky Boy 7.5 minute topographic quadrangle; latitude 38 degrees 25 minutes 38 seconds N and longitude 118 degrees 39 minutes 30 seconds W; WGS84 Decimal Degrees 38.4266667 latitude, -118.6583333 longitude.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:
Soil moisture: Usually moist in winter and spring, dry in summer and fall except for 10 to 20 days cumulative in some part between July and October due to convection storms; aridic soil moisture regime that borders on xeric.
Mean annual soil temperature: 8 to 12 degrees C.
Ochric epipedon thickness: 8 to 18 cm.
Depth to bedrock: 8 to 25 cm to a paralithic contact.  The paralithic materials below the contact are weathered granitic rocks such as granite or granodiorite.
Reaction: Neutral through slightly alkaline.
Effervescence: Noneffervescent or slightly effervescent.
Particle-size control section - Clay content: Averages 6 to 10 percent.
Rock fragments: 35 to 60 percent, mainly fine (2 to 5 mm) gravel. Lithology of fragments is granitic rocks such as granite or granodiorite.
A horizons
Value:  5 or 6 dry, 4 or 5 moist.
Chroma:  2 through 4, dry or moist.
Texture:  Very gravelly coarse sand or very gravelly loamy coarse sand; some pedons have thin A1 horizons of gravelly loamy sand or very gravelly coarse sandy loam.
Structure:  Single grain or weak subangular blocky.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  There are currently no other series in this family.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Lazan soils are on mountains and rock pediments.  They typically occur on all slope positions, but usually have a south-facing aspect.  These soils formed in residuum and colluvium from granitic rock.  Slopes are 8 to 75 percent.  Elevations range from 1,640 to 2,680 meters.  The climate is semiarid with cool, moist winters and warm, dry summers.  The mean annual precipitation is 300 to 360 mm, mean annual temperature is 7 to 10 degrees C, and the frost-free period is 90 to 120 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Nupart and Rockabin soils.  Nupart soils have mollic epipedons and a frigid temperature regime.  Rockabin soils have mollic epipedons and are moderately deep to paralithic contacts.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND SATURATED HYDRAULIC CONDUCTIVITY:  Somewhat excessively drained; very low or low surface runoff; very high saturated hydraulic conductivity.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Lazan soils are used for forestland and wildlife habitat.  The present vegetation is a forest canopy of singleleaf pinyon with an understory of green ephedra, Wyoming big sagebrush, desert needlegrass, bottlebrush squirreltail, and antelope bitterbrush.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Western Nevada.  These soils are not extensive.  The series concept and main acreage is in MLRA 26, while other acreage occurs in MLRA 29.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE:  Davis, California.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Revision of October 2002 updates the taxonomic class, from Sandy-skeletal, mixed, mesic, shallow Typic Xerorthents, because of a change in concept for moisture regime.
Diagnostic horizons and features recognized in this pedon are:
Ochric epipedon - The zone from the soil surface to 10 cm (A1 and A2 horizons).
Paralithic contact - The boundary at 10 cm to underlying weathered, fractured bedrock (Cr layer).
Particle-size control section - The zone from the soil surface to 10 cm (A1 and A2 horizons).
ADDITIONAL DATA: User Pedon ID: 2007NV021083.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
